result.text:
If you're building RAG applications, this chunking blog post might be the most important read of your week. 

Here's why:

Chunking is arguably the biggest factor in RAG performance. Even perfect retrieval systems fail if they're searching over poorly prepared data. 

Yet most developers jump straight to choosing embedding models or vector databases without getting this foundation right.

The post covers everything you need:
• 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 is chunking, and 𝘄𝗵𝘆 is it so important for RAG?
• 𝗦𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝘁𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲𝘀: Fixed-size and recursive chunking to get started quickly
• 𝗔𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱 𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗵𝗼𝗱𝘀: Semantic, LLM-based, and agentic chunking for complex documents
• 𝗦𝗽𝗲𝗰𝗶𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘇𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝗵𝗲𝘀: Late chunking, hierarchical, and adaptive strategies
• 𝗗𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗳𝗿𝗮𝗺𝗲𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀: How to choose the right strategy for your specific use case
• 𝗖𝗼𝗱𝗲 𝗲𝘅𝗮𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲𝘀: Practical Python implementations you can use immediately

Plus, we tackle the question most guides skip: "𝘋𝘰𝘦𝘴 𝘮𝘺 𝘥𝘢𝘵𝘢 𝘦𝘷𝘦𝘯 𝘯𝘦𝘦𝘥 𝘤𝘩𝘶𝘯𝘬𝘪𝘯𝘨?"

Whether you're prototyping your first RAG system or optimizing a production application, this guide gives you the tools to find the best way to prepare your data.

Read the blog: https://t.co/fGKcdRMJvB

result.text:
This shows how far we've come with the dev brainrot

Most sites don't need a multi-region edge server!

Only apps with strict latency requirements like trading, gaming, real-time collaboration apps need them, but that's an extremely small share of most apps/websites

A basic CDN that hosts assets (images, JS, CSS) at edge servers like Cloudflare is sufficient for 99% of websites/apps because it caches 95% of requests

result.text:
Fixed-size chunking is breaking your RAG system 💀

When you split text into arbitrary 200-word chunks, you're destroying the natural flow of information.

Imagine passing this to your LLM: "In the dense areas, most of the concentration is via medium- and high-rise buildings."

Without context, this sentence is useless. Where are we talking about? Why does density matter? Your LLM has to guess, and that's where hallucinations creep in.

The solution? 𝗔𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱 𝗰𝗵𝘂𝗻𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲𝘀 that understand your content:

𝗦𝗲𝗺𝗮𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗖𝗵𝘂𝗻𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴: Uses natural text boundaries like paragraphs and sections to keep related information together. Instead of arbitrary cuts, you're preserving the author's intended structure.

𝗟𝗟𝗠-𝗕𝗮𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗵𝘂𝗻𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴: Uses AI to intelligently determine where to split text based on semantic meaning and context flow.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗱𝗲-𝗼𝗳𝗳:

Variable chunk sizes mean you need to be more strategic about retrieval - smaller chunks might need more results, larger ones might contain irrelevant info.

But the payoff is HUGE: Instead of that confusing sentence fragment, you get: "Wikipedia: London: Architecture: In the dense areas, most of the concentration is via medium- and high-rise buildings. London's skyscrapers, such as 30 St Mary Axe..."

Way more context = way better RAG performance.

Chunking isn't just about splitting text - it's about preserving the semantic relationships that make information actually useful to your LLM.

Free advanced RAG techniques ebook:  https://t.co/G3PCJYnxiw

legacy.full_text:

Been using the @Zai_org offer heavily today, it's stable, it works with claude code, it's great for refactors.

All the other combos I tried (Grok Code Fast 1 + opencode) eventually fail, this one has been looping for hours and bravely adding biome linter and fixing tests in the background. Feels like Sonnet, just that the servers are in Singapore instead of the US.

result.text:
"RAG is just fancy search" - a quote that aged poorly.

The next frontier isn't just about better retrieval, it's about giving your RAG systems components that actually do more with your data.

Building RAG is easy at this point, now, we need to start going beyond that and engineering systems that include techniques, components, and strategies to ensure deterministic success in LLM-based architectures. There’s not a one-size-fits-all solution, it’s all about figuring out what is going to actually work for your use case.

So here’s a dump of some advanced prompting and reasoning techniques that can be applied to RAG pipelines:

𝗖𝗵𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗼𝗳 𝗧𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵𝘁 (𝗖𝗼𝗧): Instead of jumping straight to answers, the model breaks down complex queries into intermediate reasoning steps. This dramatically improves answer quality by making the LLM "show its work."

𝗥𝗲𝗔𝗰𝘁 (𝗥𝗲𝗮𝘀𝗼𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 + 𝗔𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴): Combines reasoning with action-taking capabilities. The agent can reason about what information it needs, act to retrieve it, then reason again based on what it found. 

𝗧𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗧𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵𝘁𝘀: Takes reasoning even further by exploring multiple reasoning paths simultaneously. Each "branch" represents a different approach to solving the problem, allowing the system to find the most effective solution path.

𝗤𝘂𝗲𝗿𝘆 𝗥𝗲𝘄𝗿𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 & 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻: The system can reformulate user queries to be more effective for retrieval. Sometimes what users ask isn't the best way to find what they actually need. 

You can find more in this ebook: https://t.co/4MGyGtwUND

result.text:
Prompt engineering is slowly dying

Enter 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗲𝘅𝘁 𝗘𝗻𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 

(Maybe not quite dead — but evolving into something far more powerful)

As AI grows from simple chatbots to 𝗮𝘂𝘁𝗼𝗻𝗼𝗺𝗼𝘂𝘀 𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀, clever prompts alone will not be enough. The real challenge is orchestrating an entire ecosystem of information and tools so the model can actually get things done.

So, what does context engineering look like in practice?

𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀:
👤 User information: Preferences, history, and personalization data
⚒️ Tools & APIs: Calculators, search engines, or anything the LLM needs to complete the task
📖 Retrieved knowledge: Dynamic info from databases or external sources
💻 User input: The task or query itself
⛓️ LLM reasoning: The chain of thought and decision-making logic
🧠 Conversation memory: Previous interactions that provide continuity

𝗠𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝗮 𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗰𝗶𝗮𝗹 𝗿𝗼𝗹𝗲:
• Short-term memory: Lives in the context window, for the current conversation
• Long-term memory: Stored externally (vector DBs, knowledge bases) to persist preferences and past interactions

LLMs aren’t mind readers. Garbage in, garbage out still applies. The difference is now we’re thinking about the 𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗿𝗲 𝗽𝗶𝗽𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗴𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗿𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁 𝗴𝗮𝗿𝗯𝗮𝗴𝗲… 𝗜 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻, 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗲𝘅𝘁… 𝘁𝗼 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗺𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗹𝘀.

The key question to ask yourself: “𝘊𝘢𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘓𝘓𝘔 𝘱𝘭𝘢𝘶𝘴𝘪𝘣𝘭𝘺 𝘢𝘤𝘤𝘰𝘮𝘱𝘭𝘪𝘴𝘩 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘵𝘢𝘴𝘬 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩 𝘸𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘐'𝘷𝘦 𝘨𝘪𝘷𝘦𝘯 𝘪𝘵?”

Context engineering isn’t just the next step after prompts, it’s 𝗯𝘂𝗶𝗹𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘀𝗲𝘁 𝗔𝗜 𝘂𝗽 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹 𝘀𝘂𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀.

result.text:
Agents alone can't do much

They need structure, roles, and workflows to be truly effective.

AI agents combine three core components to function effectively:

• 𝗟𝗟𝗠𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘀𝗼𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 - the brain that makes decisions
• 𝗧𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 - the hands that get things done
• 𝗠𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆 - the experience that improves performance over time

𝗦𝗼 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗲𝘅𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗹𝘆 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗳𝗹𝗼𝘄𝘀?

An agentic workflow is a series of connected steps dynamically executed by agents to achieve specific goals.

Unlike traditional workflows that follow rigid, predetermined paths, agentic workflows adapt and evolve.

𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗳𝗹𝗼𝘄 "𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗰"?

The magic happens when agents can

✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗮 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝗻 - break down complex tasks into manageable sub-tasks
✅ 𝗘𝘅𝗲𝗰𝘂𝘁𝗲 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀 - interact with real-world systems and data
✅ 𝗔𝗱𝗮𝗽𝘁 𝗱𝘆𝗻𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 - adjust based on new information and feedback

Think of it this way: a regular AI workflow might summarize text when prompted. An agentic workflow can decide whether summarization is needed, choose the best approach, execute it, and refine the result based on feedback.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗸𝗲𝘆 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲?

Non-agentic workflows use static AI models. Agentic workflows use dynamic agents that can reason, plan, and adapt.

This makes them more responsive and intelligent, but also more complex to implement.

𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗹-𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗹𝗱 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗰𝘁:

Instead of rigid "if-then" rules, agentic workflows can handle nuanced scenarios. For example, a dinner planning agent can consider dietary restrictions, cuisine preferences, guest count, and even wine pairings - all while adapting to new constraints in real-time.

The bottom line? Agentic workflows represent a shift from programmed automation to intelligent orchestration. They're not just following scripts - they're thinking, planning, and adapting.

Learn more about the structure and functionality of agentic workflows in our blog post: https://t.co/K7SMWkAdti

result.text:
New in-depth blog post - "Inside vLLM: Anatomy of a High-Throughput LLM Inference System". Probably the most in depth explanation of how LLM inference engines and vLLM in particular work!

Took me a while to get this level of understanding of the codebase and then to write up this one - i quickly realized i understimated the effort. 😅 It could have easily been a book/booklet (lol).

I covered:

* Basics of inference engine flow (input/output request processing, scheduling, paged attention, continuous batching)

* "Advanced" stuff: chunked prefill, prefix caching, guided decoding (grammar-constrained FSM), speculative decoding, disaggregated P/D

* Scaling up: going from smaller LMs that can be hosted on a single GPU all the way to trillion+ params (via TP/PP/SP) -> multi-GPU, multi-node setup

* Serving the model on the web: going from offline deployment to multiple API servers, load balancing, DP coordinator, multiple engines setup :)

* Measuring perf of inference systems (latency (ttft, itl, e2e, tpot), throughput) and GPU perf roofline model

Lots of examples, lots of visuals!

---

I realize i've been silent on social - many of you noticed and thanks for reaching out! :) --> I'm so back! lots of things happened.

Also, in general, I'm a bit sick of superficial content, it really is an equivalent of junk food (h/t @karpathy).

I want to do the best/deepest technical work of my life over the next years and write much more in depth (high quality organic food ;)) so I might not be as frequent around here as i used to be (? we'll see). I'll make it a goal to share a few paper summaries a week or stuff that's relevant / in the zeitgeist.

If you have any topics that happened over the past few weeks/months drop it down in the comments i might focus on some of those in my next posts.

---

Huge thank you to @Hyperstackcloud for giving me an H100 node to run some of the experiments and analysis that i needed to write this up. The team there led by Christopher Starkey is amazing!

Also a big thank you to Nick Hill (who did a very thorough review of the post - basically a code review lol; Nick's a core vLLM contributor and principal SWE at RedHat) and to my friends Kyle Krannen (NVIDIA Dynamo), @marksaroufim (PyTorch), and @ashVaswani (goat) for taking the time during weekend when they didn't have to!

result.text:
A few years ago I realized that if I’m too busy to take something on, I shouldn’t say “I don’t have the time”. In fact, I often do have the time. It’s not that hard to squeeze in some extra time for someone.

What I don’t have – and what I can’t squeeze in – is more attention. Attention is a far more limited resource than time. So what I should say is “I don’t have the attention”. I may have 8 hours a day for work, but I probably have 4 hours a day for attention.

One summer, a guy wrote me out of the blue asking if he could intern for me. His email was great – clear, thoughtful, kind, inviting, confident but not pushy, and not too long (but long enough to say what he had to say without leaving anything out). He was studying at Harvard Business School and was going to be back in Chicago that summer.

He asked if he could swing by and say hi. His email made it easy for me to say yes. So he did, and we had a great session. We spent maybe an hour or so together. I learned about his background, what kind of stuff he was interested in, what he wanted to learn, what he could teach us, etc. Then we riffed on a few ideas. It was natural, flowing, effortless. Really promising.

Then I told him I’d think a few things over and get back to him soon. He checked in a few weeks later, and I said I’d get back to him soon again. And I didn’t.

A month or so after that I wrote him and told him I was really sorry. I’d mislead him – and myself – thinking I had enough time to take on a intern that summer. I wanted to, I really liked him, I thought he’d be great, but I just didn’t have as much time as I thought I had to even consider it more and line up work and spend time with him, etc.

But really, as I thought about it, I realized I had the time. Every day is the same 24 hour cycle. Every workday around 8 hours. Surely I could have found even 20 minutes a day to work with him. But it wasn’t that. It wasn’t that I couldn’t find the time. I couldn’t find the attention — especially sustained attention.

My mind fills up with a few key projects and that’s it. I’m absorbed by those. That’s where my attention is. Had I made 20 minutes here and there for him, I’d be physically present in that moment, but mentally I’d be elsewhere. And that’s not fair to either of us.

Time and attention aren’t the same thing. They're barely related.

legacy.description: @ContextualAI CEO, @Stanford Adjunct Prof.

result.text:
Context becomes even more critical when you move from single-source to multi-source RAG. Dropping one document into ChatGPT? Context is straightforward. Enterprise AI that requires thousands of documents spread across Salesforce, Gong, SharePoint, Google Drive, Box? Now you’re managing a web of contextual relationships between systems.

Beyond connectors, you're solving:

- Identity reconciliation - mapping john.smith@company.com to J.Smith to Johnny across systems
- Cross-system context - understanding that a Gong call relates to a Salesforce opp and a Drive contract
- Metadata normalization - unifying how different sources tag and structure data
- Distributed entitlements - ensuring AI respects access controls from each source
- Intelligent reranking - prioritizing potentially conflicting results across disparate systems and document types

Single-source RAG retrieves documents. Multi-source context engineering reconstructs business context from fragments scattered across your enterprise stack.

result.text:
Multimodal RAG over PDFs with ColQwen2 
(without any OCR, layout detection, or chunking).

In this tutorial, my colleague Tobias and I show you how to build a multimodal RAG pipeline over PDFs:

• Embed screenshots of PDF pages as images with a multimodal late-interaction model, ColQwen2
• Store in a @weaviate_io vector database
• Embed text query with ColQwen2 to retrieve PDFs from the database at query time
• Generate an answer with VLM Qwen2.5-VL

GitHub: https://t.co/b5FmXSWYlF

legacy.description: cofounder/cto @boldmetrics

result.text:
The two biggest life hacks I’ve made that have changed everything for me ⬇️ 

1. Do what you actually love, not just what gives you the biggest paycheck

2. Live in your favorite vacation spot so that when you take a break, you’re doing it in a place most other people only go to on vacation 

Now this doesn’t mean I’m never stressed, or have found some magical work life balance. I work a lot - days, nights, weekends - but when I’m not working, even for 20 minutes, the reset I get is massive.

And the work I do, is exactly what I want to do, and is something I firmly believe is, and will continue to, change the world.

Life is short - choose wisely.
